Vassilis, we could in fact insert a hidden layer (i.e. a new "slice") int=
o the state-space sandwich in Keepaway.  It is probably true that there are=
 some more complex behaviors that could be learned that way than with the c=
urrent setup.  However, the cost would be slower learning and since the cur=
rent setup is sufficient for the Keepaway task, it may not be really import=
ant for that task.  However, if the task was made more complex, it could be=
come necessary.

Note that even if the substrate was not allowed to evolve,=
 we could still insert the hidden layer at a fixed resolution.  We could al=
so allow the hidden layer node placement to evolve as well.  It's difficult=
 to say the impact of that idea on this domain since the evolvable substrat=
e (ES-HyperNEAT) is such a new approach, but I would guess again that the c=
urrent task setup would not really need it, though it might be useful as it=
 gets more complex.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "v.vassiliades" <vas=
silisvas@...> wrote:
>
> Hi all and Happy Easter,
> 
> 
> I liked the ideas=
 in your new papers:
> - Evolving the Placement and Density of Neurons in t=
he HyperNEAT Substrate
> - Transfer Learning through Indirect Encodng
> 
> =
I was wondering whether you had any thoughts about combining them. More spe=
cifically, by allowing hidden nodes inside the "state-space sandwich" confi=
guration. 
> 
> Do you think it makes sense to have hidden nodes between th=
e input and output sheets of neurons?
> 
> 
> Thanks,
> 
> Vassilis
>
